Description: THE WILDLIFE ECOLOGY INSTITUTES MISSION IS TO BUILD UPON THE EXISTING FOUNDATION FOR MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF KIT FOXES, A SPECIES THAT IS SENSITIVE TO EFFECTS OF PERTURBATIONS IN THEIR SEMI-ARID ENVIRONMENT.

IN ORDER TO EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE BLMS SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS, UPDATED INFORMATION CONCERNING THEIR CURRENT CONSERVATION STATUS, DISTRIBUTION, AND ABUNDANCE ON BLM LANDS AND ELSEWHERE IS NEEDED. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE BLM WITH CURRENT AND COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATION ON RARE PLANT SPECIES FOR WASHINGTON STATE IN ORDER TO UTILIZE SCIENCE TO IDENTIFY THE BEST PRACTICES TO MANAGE LAND AND CONSERVE SPECIES. SPECIFICALLY, WNHP WILL (1) INCORPORATE DATA COLLECTED BY BLM INTO THE WNHP STATEWIDE DATABASE ON RARE SPECIES AND CONDUCT BIANNUAL DATA EXCHANGES WITH BLM  AND (2) ASSESS THE VULNERABILITY OF BLMS SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES IN WASHINGTON TO CLIMATE CHANGE. PROJECT OUTPUTS WILL ADDRESS THE STRATEGIC GOALS OF THE BLM OREGON WASHINGTON THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES PROGRAM TO (1) PROVIDE COMPLETE, CURRENT, AND ACCURATE INFORMATION ON THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF BLM SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS TO INCREASE PROFESSIONAL AND PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF THESE RESOURCES  (2) COLLECT DATA AND INFORMATION TO ASSESS THREATS AND SPECIES HABITAT RESPONSES TO PROACTIVE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR BLM SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES  AND (3) INCREASE PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE OF BLM SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE SCOPE AND SCALE OF BLM-INVESTMENT IN THE BLACKFOOT WATERSHED THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF SHARED ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION AND RESILIENCY GOALS ACROSS NONFEDERAL LANDS, NEARLY 642,000 ACRES. THE BLACKFOOT WATERSHED COMPRISES THE MAJORITY OF THE MISSOULA BLACKFOOT-CLARK FORK NATIONAL FOCAL LANDSCAPE SELECTED FOR TARGETED INVESTMENT OF INFLATION REDUCTION ACT FUNDS, AND 44 PERCENT OF THE BLACKFOOT WATERSHED IS IN NON-FEDERAL MANAGEMENT. THE BLACKFOOT LANDSCAPE AND COMMUNITY RESILIENCY PROGRAM THROUGH THE BLACKFOOT CHALLENGE WILL LEVERAGE IRA FUNDING AND APPLY IT TO NON-FEDERAL LANDS IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE TRANSFORMATIONAL ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION AND RESILIENCE IN THE BLACKFOOT WATERSHED FOR THE BENEFIT OF SENSITIVE WILDLIFE SPECIES AND RURAL COMMUNITIES. THE PROJECT CAPITALIZES ON THE BLACKFOOT CHALLENGE S LONGSTANDING COLLABORATIVE ACHIEVEMENTS AND ROBUST NETWORK OF CONSERVATION AND LANDOWNER PARTNERS TO INVEST THIS ONCE-IN-A GENERATION OPPORTUNITY IN THE AREAS OF RIPARIAN RESTORATION AND WILDLIFE CONFLICT REDUCTION. THIS PROJECT STRATEGICALLY TARGETS AREAS WHERE PARTNERS CAN HAVE A DISPROPORTIONATE AND POSITIVE IMPACT ON SPECIES RECOVERY. KEY CONSERVATION BENEFITS FROM THIS PROPOSAL WILL INCLUDE: REDUCING HUMAN-CAUSED GRIZZLY BEAR MORTALITY BY MAKING HABITAT MORE USABLE FOR BEARS AND OTHER WILDLIFE AND INCREASING HABITAT CONNECTIVITY. OTHER CONSERVATION OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVING ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS OF RIPARIAN AREAS THAT PROVIDE CONCENTRATED CRITICAL HABITAT FOR NEARLY ALL SENSITIVE SPECIES IN THE WATERSHED. BY FOCUSING ON GRIZZLY BEARS AND BULL TROUT IN THIS CASE, WE ARE TAKING AN UMBRELLA SPECIES APPROACH WITH ANCILLARY BENEFITS TO A WIDE SWATH OF SPECIES THAT DEPEND ON SIMILAR HABITATS IN ADDITION TO IMPROVING THE ECONOMIC RESILIENCY OF RURAL LIVELIHOODS DEPENDENT ON THE SAME NATURAL RESOURCES.

THE MISSION OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A RESOURCE TO SHARE COLLECTIVE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE SENSITIVE VASCULAR PLANTS OF OREGON AND PRESENT THE DATA WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF OREGONS COMPREHENSIVE PLANT DIVERSITY.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00162FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT: BEES ARE HIGHLY IMPORTANT POLLINATORS WITH SUBSTANTIAL ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC SIGNIFICANCE. SUBSTANTIAL WORLDWIDE DECLINES OF POLLINATORS, INCLUDING BEES, ARE REPORTED AND MANY OF THESE SPECIES MAY BECOME LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED SPECIES. THERE IS VERY LITTLE DISTRIBUTIONAL INFORMATION FOR POLLINATORS, INCLUDING BEES. DISTRIBUTIONAL INFORMATION IS CRUCIAL FOR BLMS ABILITY TO CONSERVE BEES ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE. THE PROPOSAL TARGETS 5 BEE SPECIES, ALL OF WHICH HAVE BEEN PETITIONED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ESA.  FOCUSING ON SPECIES PETITIONED FOR LISTING IS ESPECIALLY RELEVANT GIVEN THAT INFORMATION MAY BE VALUABLE FOR FWS EVALUATION OF SPECIES STATUS OR IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION STRATEGIES.  THE TECHNICAL APPROACH CLEARLY IDENTIFIES 6 ACTIONS TO SURVEY BEES AND BETTER UNDERSTAND THEIR DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND HABITAT USE ON BLM LANDS. THE ACTIONS INCLUDE OUTREACH, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO VOLUNTEERS ACROSS COLORADO, NEVADA, UTAH, AND WYOMING, THE PROVISION OF SURVEY KITS TO VOLUNTEERS, AND DEVELOPMENT OF A WEBSITE PORTAL. THE PROPOSAL ALSO INCLUDES ONGOING MANAGEMENT AND ANALYSIS OF THE DATABASE AND THE DELIVERY OF PRESENTATIONS AND FIELD VISITS.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00162FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:  THIS PROJECT CONTINUES WORK FROM PREVIOUS AGREEMENTS TO EVALUATE AND FILL KNOWLEDGE GAPS ABOUT BLM SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES (SSS).  CURRENT AND ACCURATE INFORMATION ON SSS STATUS AND LOCATIONS IS CRUCIAL FOR BLMS ABILITY TO MANAGE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS, INCLUDING UNDER CHANGING CLIMATE CONDITIONS.  THE INFORMATION ALSO SUPPORTS ACCURATE NEPA EVALUATIONS AND ESA SECTION 7(A)(2) CONSULTATIONS.  THE TECHNICAL APPROACH CLEARLY LAYS OUT PROJECT OBJECTIVES WITH SPECIFIC TASKS THAT ARE CLEAR AND APPLICABLE TO ACHIEVING STATED NEEDS AND RESULTS FOR UPDATED TAXONOMY, LOCATION INFORMATION, HABITAT MODELING, STATUS ASSESSMENT, AND SPECIES PRIORITIZATION.  THE APPROACH BUILDS OFF 3 PREVIOUS YEARS OF WORK TO ENSURE UPDATED SSS INFORMATION.  COLLECT AN TO DATE SSS LISTS AND ALIGN WITH CURRENT TAXONOMY.  IDENTIFY, REVIEW, AND RESOLVE TAXONOMIC MISMATCHES, GENERATE INTEGRATED SSS LIST.  ASSES DATA GAPS, PRODUCE AND DELIVER SSS HABITAT AND DISTRIBUTION MAPS, PRODUCE ANALYSES AN VISUAL SUMMARIES OF BLM STEWARDSHIP RESPONSIBILITIES FOR SSS.  UPDATE AND REPORT SSS CONSERVATION STATUS RANKS AND WORK WITH BLM TO IDENTIFY PRIORITY SPECIES FOR REVIEW.  APPLY SSS PRIORITIZATION RULESET TO SENSITIVE SPECIES.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP AND COMMUNICATE SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION ON CRINITE MARIPOSA LILY, A BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES, AND THE SURROUNDING PLANT COMMUNITY, AS WELL AS DEVELOP AND IMPROVE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES.THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: ASSESSING THE POPULATION STATUS OF CRINITE MARIPOSA LILY ON LANDS MANAGED BY THE ROSEBURG BLM  DEVELOPING PLANT MATERIALS AND PROPAGATION PROTOCOLS TO INFORM POPULATION AUGMENTATION EFFORTS  AND CONDUCTING OUTPLANTINGS OF THIS SPECIES TO BOLSTER DECLINING WILD POPULATIONS.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00162FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:  THIS PROPOSAL CONTINUES WORK THAT STARTED 3 YEARS AGO TO IMPROVE THE FLOW OF SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES OBSERVATION DATA BETWEEN BLM HQ, FIELD OFFICES, AND STATE NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAMS BY LINKING THROUGH THE NATURESERVE PORTAL. BLM REQUIRES EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE ACCESS TO THIS TYPE OF BIOLOGICAL AND LOCATION INFORMATION TO SUCCESSFULLY CONSERVE THREATENED, ENDANGERED, AND SENSITIVE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS. IT IS IMPORTANT THAT THE INFORMATION SHARED IS CONSISTENTLY COLLECTED AND SHARED WITH INVOLVED PARTIES. THIS PROPOSAL ALSO CONTINUES WORK TO COLLECT NEW INFORMATION AND REMAP THOUSANDS OF EXISTING SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES LOCATION RECORDS INTO STANDARDIZED FORMATS, MAKING THEM AVAILABLE FOR BLM USE. THE PROPOSAL IS RELEVANT GIVEN INCREASING NEED TO INFORM CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN LIGHT OF INCREASING USES OF BLM LANDS.  INFORMATION COLLECTED THROUGH THIS PROPOSAL IS SHARED WITH THE PUBLIC THROUGH NATURESERVES WEBSITE, INCREASING PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE STATUS AND CONSERVATION NEEDS OF THREATENED, ENDANGERED, AND SENSITIVE SPECIES. CITIZEN SCIENTISTS CAN ALSO BECOME MORE INVOLVED IN PROVIDING ACCURATE INFORMATION THROUGH DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF THE STANDARDIZED FIELD DATA COLLECTION FORMS.  THE TECHNICAL APPROACH CLEARLY LAYS OUT 5 PROJECT OBJECTIVES WITH SPECIFIC TASKS THAT ARE CLEAR AND APPLICABLE TO ACHIEVING STATED NEEDS AND RESULTS. THE APPROACH BUILDS OFF 3 PREVIOUS YEARS OF WORK TO ENSURE COLLABORATION, TRAINING, AND USE OF NEW DATA FORMS IN 5 STATES. EFFORTS WILL BE EXPANDED ACROSS ADDITIONAL STATES IN THIS PROPOSAL, WITH 2 NEW STATES IN YEAR 1. THE PROPOSAL ALSO DESCRIBES LESSONS LEARNED FROM THE PREVIOUS 3 YEAR EFFORT AND PROPOSES SOLUTIONS MOVING FORWARD WHICH IS LIKELY TO INCREASE SUCCESS OF THE APPROACH.  1. SURVEYING BLM NEEDS, EXPANDING UNDERSTANDING AND USE OF FIELD FORMS, PROVIDING TRAINING THROUGH WEBINARS, MEETINGS, AND DEVELOPMENT OF MATERIALS. 2. IDENTIFY 2 NEW STATES, DOCUMENT DATA EXCHANGE PLAN AND FREQUENCY, IDENTIFY FIELD USERS, SURVEY PRE-EXISTING DATA FOR CROSSWALK INTO FIELD SURVEY TEMPLATE, ENGAGING STAFF IN SURVEY DESIGN, TESTING, AND IMPLEMENTATION.  3. DOCUMENT DATA UPDATES DELIVERY OF AGGREGATED OBSERVATION DATA.  4. LAUNCH MOBILE ENABLED MAP OF FIELD OBSERVATIONS, INCORPORATE EOS AND SOURCE FEATURES, INCORPORATE SPECIES HABITAT MODELS AND RANGE MAPS.  5. CONDUCT TAXONOMIC BREAKDOWN OF OBSERVATION IN EACH STATE, SUMMARIZE NEW SSS RECORDS AND IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC AND TAXONOMIC GAPS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO REMOVE LIVESTOCK CARCASSES FROM THE LANDSCAPE TO MINIMIZE HUMAN-BEAR CONFLICT AND INCREASE HUMAN SAFETY. THIS PROGRAM IS AN ALTERNATIVE TO STORING CARCASSES IN TRADITIONAL BONEYARDS WHICH MAY ATTRACT AND HOLD GRIZZLY BEARS NEAR HUMANS, RANCH BUILDING, AND CALVING AREAS. THIS PROGRAM PROVIDES A COST-EFFICIENT WAY FOR ALL PRODUCERS TO DISPOSE OF A SIGNIFICANT GRIZZLY BEAR ATTRACTANT, DECREASING THE CHANCE OF RECURRING HUMAN-BEAR CONFLICT.

HYGROTUS DIVERSIPES WAS DESCRIBED BY HUGH LEECH IN 1964 FROM DUGOUT CREEK NORTHWEST OF MIDWEST, WYOMING. HYGROTUS DIVERSIPES WAS A CATEGORY II CANDIDATE SPECIES UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) FROM 1984 TO 1996 UNTIL THAT DESIGNATION WAS DISCONTINUED. THE BEETLE HAS BEEN PETITIONED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ESA THREE TIMES SINCE 2007 AND IS CURRENTLY BEING REVIEWED FOR ESA LISTING BY THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. HYGROTUS DIVERSIPES IS ENDEMIC TO CENTRAL WYOMING AND RELATIVELY LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THEIR LIFE HISTORY AND LIFECYCLE. WE PROPOSE TO COLLECT DATA ON THE BEETLE TO PROVIDE THE BLM AND US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO HELP MANAGE THIS SPECIES.WE PROPOSE TO INVESTIGATE HOW H. DIVERSIPES MAY RESPOND TO FUTURE STREAM CONDITIONS UNDER A CHANGING CLIMATE AS WELL AS MONITOR THEIR POPULATIONS AND SEARCH FOR NEW POPULATIONS. FUTURE PROJECTIONS OF CLIMATE PREDICT WARMER AND DRIER CONDITIONS. WE OBSERVED THAT WARMER AND DRIER CONDITIONS RESULTED IN SALTIER STREAMS (HIGH SPECIFIC CONDUCTIVITY). HYGROTUS DIVERSIPES ALREADY LIVES IN SALTY STREAMS IN WYOMING. THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP DEFINE WHAT CONDITIONS THEY CAN SURVIVE IN AND PREDICT IF CURRENT SUITABLE HABITAT WILL BE SUITABLE IN THE FUTURE. WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE TO MONITOR POPULATIONS TO UNDERSTAND BASIC LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION SUCH AS WHERE ARE LARVAL REARING HABITATS, HOW LONG DO LARVAE TAKE TO DEVELOP, WHAT HABITAT REQUIREMENT DO BEETLES HAVE IN DIFFERENT LIFE STAGES, HOW OFTEN DO ADULTS DISPERSE, ETC. WE DEVELOPED METHODS OF CATCH AND RELEASE SO THAT WE ARE MINIMALLY DISTURBING INVERTEBRATE POPULATIONS IN THESE STREAMS. WE ARE MONITORING STREAM HYDROLOGY TO ESTIMATE WHAT CONDITIONS THESE BEETLES PREFER. WE HAVE ALSO PROPOSED EFFORTS TO SEARCH FOR NEW POPULATIONS IN THE BASINS IN WYOMING. INFORMATION FROM OUR STUDY WILL PROVIDE BASIC INFORMATION ABOUT THIS RARE BEETLE SO THAT MORE INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS CAN BE MADE. THIS WILL BENEFIT THE BLM BY PROVIDING INFORMATION ABOUT CURRENT AND FUTURE SUITABLE HABITAT, WHAT CONDITIONS THE BEETLES CAN SURVIVE IN AND BASIC INFORMATION ABOUT HABITAT REQUIREMENT FOR LARVAL AND ADULT STAGES. OCCUPANCY IS COMPLEX FOR H. DIVERSIPES AND GATHERING MORE DETAILED INFORMATION ABOUT OCCURRENCES WILL HELP US TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND MANAGE THEIR USE OF THE LANDSCAPE NOW AND INTO THE FUTURE.WE PROPOSE TO MONITOR THE 9 STREAMS THAT HYGROTUS DIVERSIPES IS KNOWN FROM EVERY 2-4 WEEKS. WE WILL MONITOR CORE SITES (POOLS BY BARNUM, TRIBUTARY TO MURPHY CREEK, DUGOUT CREEK, GOVERNMENT CREEK, DEAD HORSE CREEK, 2 SITES ON CLOUD CREEK) EVERY 2 WEEKS AND WE WILL MONITOR MORE DISTANT SITES MONTHLY (CONANT CREEK, BUD KIMBALL CREEK, AND NOWATER CREEK). MONITORING INVOLVES WALKING FOR  2 HOURS ALONG EACH STREAM AND SAMPLING FOR INVERTEBRATES USING A DIPNET USING CATCH AND RELEASE TECHNIQUES FOR MOST TAXA. WE WILL MEASURE WATER QUALITY IN POOLS AND OTHER HABITAT INFORMATION (FISH PRESENCE, POOL CHARACTERISTICS, GRAZING AND LAND USE). WE WILL COLLECT A PORTION OF H. DIVERSIPES (LARVAE AND ADULTS) WE FIND AND BRING INDIVIDUALS BACK TO THE LABORATORY TO MEASURE THEIR SURVIVAL AND GROWTH IN DIFFERENT CONDUCTIVITY WATER (100  50,000 S CM). A WARMING CLIMATE WILL LIKELY INCREASE THE CONDUCTIVITY OF THE WATER IN THE STREAMS WHERE THEY LIVE AND WE WILL ESTIMATE IF THEY CAN LIVE IN HIGHER AND LOWER CONCENTRATIONS. WE HAVE FOUND THEM IN STREAMS WITH CONDUCTIVITY BETWEEN  5000 AND 25,000 S CM. INDIVIDUALS WILL BE RELEASED BACK INTO THE STREAMS WE COLLECTED THEM IN ONCE EXPERIMENTS ARE COMPLETE. WE WILL ALSO PERFORM CHOICE EXPERIMENTS TO SEE IF THEY PREFER LOWER OR HIGHER CONDUCTIVITY WATER USING SIMPLE CHOICE CHAMBERS. FINALLY, WE WILL USE PROTEIN PRODUCTION TO ESTIMATE STRESS AT DIFFERENT CONDUCTIVITIES USING GENETIC TECHNIQUES.

DESERT YELLOWHEAD IS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (USDI FISH AND WILDLIFESERVICE 2002). THERE ARE ONLY TWO KNOWN POPULATIONS OF DESERT YELLOWHEAD IN THE WORLD, BOTHPOPULATIONS OCCUR ON LANDS MANAGED BY THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) LANDER FIELD OFFICE. IN2021 WE INITIATED A STUDY THAT MEASURED BOTH SEXUAL AND ASEXUAL REPRODUCTIVE BIOLOGY, WHILE MEASURINGWEATHER CONDITIONS TO ESTIMATE THE DEGREE TO WHICH MOISTURE LIMITED THIS THREATENED PLANT. THE CURRENTPROJECT ENDS IN 2023, BUT CONTINUAL DROUGHT CONDITIONS WILL LIKELY LIMIT OUR INFERENCE ABOUT REPRODUCTIONIN THIS PLANT. WE ARE PROPOSING TO CONTINUE TO MONITOR CLIMATE AND MEASURE REPRODUCTION, AS WELL ASCONDUCT MONITORING FOR BOTH POPULATIONS.OUR PROPOSAL DEVELOPED FROM THE CURRENT INTERESTS IN MONITORING RARE SPECIES (AS STATED BY THE U.S. FISHAND WILDLIFE SERVICE IN THE 2019 DESERT YELLOWHEAD SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT), THE POTENTIAL DECREASE INANNUAL PRECIPITATION, INCREASES IN AIR TEMPERATURE AND EVAPOTRANSPIRATION, AND THE LACK OF KNOWLEDGE ABOUTTHE ECOLOGY AND REPRODUCTION OF DESERT YELLOWHEAD. WE PROPOSE TO MEASURE SEED PRODUCTION TO ASCERTAINTHE DEGREE TO WHICH SOIL MOISTURE AND TEMPERATURE LIMITS THE NUMBER, MASS AND VIABILITY OF SEEDSPRODUCED BY DESERT YELLOWHEAD. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MONITORING BASED ON PASTRESEARCH IN BOTH DESERT YELLOWHEAD POPULATIONS TO ESTIMATE CHANGES IN POPULATIONS OVER TIME. WE WILLCOLLECT POLLINATORS IN BOTH POPULATIONS TO MONITOR THE BEES THAT POLLINATE THIS PLANT USING INFORMATION FROMOUR PREVIOUS STUDY AND GLOBAL DECLINES IN POLLINATORSIN 2018, 2021 AND 2022, WE COLLECTED DESERT YELLOWHEAD SEEDS AS PART OF A POLLINATION AND SEED SET STUDY,BECAUSE SPECIALIZED PLANTS CAN HAVE SPECIALIZED POLLINATORS. IF THESE SPECIALIZED POLLINATORS DECLINE, SEEDPRODUCTION CAN BE GREATLY REDUCED. HOWEVER, WE DISCOVERED THAT POLLINATORS DID NOT LIMIT SEED PRODUCTIONIN DESERT YELLOWHEAD DURING THE YEARS OF OUR STUDIES, BUT SOMETHING ELSE DID. FIFTEEN PERCENT OF SEEDSWERE VIABLE IN THE INSECT POLLINATED TREATMENT OF THE SAND DRAW POPULATION AND 1  OF SEEDS WERE VIABLE INTHE CEDAR RIM POPULATION. AFTER CONSIDERING POTENTIAL FACTORS THAT MIGHT REDUCE SEED PRODUCTION, WE FELTTHAT MOISTURE AND SUMMER TEMPERATURE MIGHT BE MOST LIMITING TO DESERT YELLOWHEAD. THE AREA THAT DESERTYELLOWHEAD IS ENDEMIC TO IS A SEMI-ARID ENVIRONMENT AND RECENT YEARS HAVE BEEN PLAGUED WITH DROUGHT.WE HAVE BEEN RESEARCHING CLIMATE VARIABLES IN RELATION DESERT YELLOWHEAD TO REPRODUCTION FOR TWO YEARS.ADAPTATIONS TO HIGH TEMPERATURES AND VARIABLE PRECIPITATION MAY CONTRIBUTE TO THE RESILIENCE OF DESERTYELLOWHEAD TO CLIMATE CHANGE  HOWEVER, DESERT YELLOWHEAD HAS LIMITS AS TO HOW HIGH OF MAXIMUMTEMPERATURES AND HOW DRY OF CONDITIONS IT WILL THRIVE UNDER. WE NEED MORE DATA TO UNDERSTAND THE IDEALTEMPERATURE RANGE FOR DESERT YELLOWHEAD TO PRODUCE VIABLE SEEDS, AND THE INFLUENCES OF OTHER BIOTIC ANDABIOTIC FACTORS.CONTINUING TO STUDY THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE ON THE REPRODUCTION OF DESERT YELLOWHEAD WOULD PROVIDE AMUCH BETTER DEPICTION OF THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE POPULATIONS TO FURTHER PROTECT THIS THREATENED PLANT. APRACTICAL AND INFORMATIVE MONITORING SCHEME WILL ALSO APPRISE THE BLM OF WHAT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS MAYBE BENEFICIAL TO CONSERVE THIS RARE SPECIES. RESULTS MAY BE USED TO ADDRESS QUESTIONS RAISED IN THE RECOVERYPLAN FOR THIS THREATENED SPECIES. DATA WILL BE STORED AND AVAILABLE FOR USE FROM WYNDDS WEBSITE(HTTPS:  WYNDD.ORG DATA EXPLORER.PHP).

SEVERAL BUMBLE BEE SPECIES ACROSS NORTH AMERICA HAVE EXPERIENCED DRASTIC POPULATION DECLINESIN THE LAST FEW DECADES INCLUDING THE WESTERN BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS OCCIDENTALIS), SUCKLEYSCUCKOO BUMBLE BEE (B. SUCKLEYI), AMERICAN BUMBLE BEE (B. PENSYLVANICUS) AND SOUTHERNPLAINS BUMBLE BEE (B. FRATERNUS). ALL OF THESE SPECIES ARE BEING CONSIDERED FOR FEDERAL PROTECTIONUNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) CURRENTLY.THE DECLINE OF BUMBLE BEES IS PARTICULARLY DISTURBING CONSIDERING THAT THEY ARE HIGHLY EFFICIENTGENERALIST POLLINATORS THAT PROVIDE VITAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICES TO FLORAL HABITATS AND AGRICULTURALCROPS. THE DECLINES WERE SO PRONOUNCED THAT THE WESTERN AND AMERICAN BUMBLE BEES WERECLASSIFIED AS VULNERABLE, THE SOUTHERN PLAINS BUMBLE BEE WAS RANKED AS ENDANGERED ANDSUCKLEYS CUCKOO BUMBLE BEE AS CRITICALLY ENDANGERED BY THE INTERNATIONAL UNION FORCONSERVATION OF NATURE (IUCN 2015). CAUSES OF BUMBLE BEE DECLINES INCLUDE HABITAT DEGRADATIONAND FRAGMENTATION, PESTICIDE APPLICATION, AND PERHAPS MOST NOTABLY, INTRODUCING NON-NATIVEPARASITES FROM COMMERCIAL COLONIES USED PRIMARILY FOR GREENHOUSE POLLINATION (DEFENDERS OFWILDLIFE 2015, CENTER FOR BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY 2020). BEES USED IN AGRICULTURE AND GARDENING(E.G., BUMBLE BEES, HONEYBEES AND ALFALFA LEAFCUTTER BEES) MAY BE SOURCES OF PARASITES FOR NATIVEBEES IN WYOMING. RECENT ACTIONS HAVE CALLED FOR MANAGEMENT OF SUCH BEES AND ALMOST NOTHING ISKNOWN ABOUT PARASITISM OF BEES IN THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO BUILD UPON PREVIOUS EFFORTS BY IAE TO ASSESS THE EFFECTS OF RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON FEDERALLY LISTED AND BUREAU SENSITIVE SPECIES, INTRODUCE AND AUGMENT POPULATIONS OF LISTED AND BUREAU SENSITIVE SPECIES, AND TO RESTORE HABITAT ON BLM LANDS MANAGED BY THE UPPER WILLAMETTE FIELD OFFICE (UWFO), NORTHWEST OREGON DISTRICT THROUGH HABITAT RESTORATION AND MONITORING.
NV CESU CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF MONARCH BUTTERFLIES IN LYON AND DOUGLAS COUNTIES, NV
NV CESU CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF WESTERN YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOOS  COCCYZUS AMERICANUS  ON THE WALKER RIVER CORRIDOR

THE GOAL THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD UPON PREVIOUS EFFORTS BY THE INSTITUTE OF APPLIED ECOLOGY (IAE) TO BOLSTER POPULATIONS OF LISTED SPECIES ACROSS THE TILLAMOOK FIELD OFFICE, NORTHWEST OREGON DISTRICT THROUGH HABITAT RESTORATION AND MONITORING. LISTED SPECIES IN THE TILLAMOOK FIELD OFFICE ARE AT RISK DUE TO LOGGING ACTIVITIES (I.E., HAULING TIMBER), ENCROACHMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES, FOREST SUCCESSION, LACK OF FIRE, AND EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. WITH SUCH THREATS, CONSERVING, RESTORING, AND EXPANDING HABITATS FOR THESE SPECIES IS CRITICAL FOR THEIR PERSISTENCE AND POTENTIAL DOWNLISTING OR DELISTING.WITHIN THE TILLAMOOK FIELD OFFICE THERE ARE NUMEROUS SITES THAT HOST LISTED SPECIES OR HAVE SUITABLE HABITAT TO HOST LISTED SPECIES. WE PROPOSE TO WORK WITH BLM STAFF AND IDENTIFY HIGH PRIORITY SITES FOR RESTORATION, DEVELOP SITE SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT PLANS AND IMPLEMENT ACTIONS. IN ADDITION, IAE STAFF WILL MONITOR RARE SPECIES (E.G., FENDERS BLUE BUTTERFLY) AND PERFORM HABITAT ASSESSMENTS AT RESTORATION SITES. RARE SPECIES MONITORING WILL BE DETERMINED BASED ON BLM REQUIREMENTS AND HABITAT ASSESSMENTS WILL OCCUR PRIOR TO THE ONSET OF RESTORATION ACTIONS AT NEW PROJECT SITES. ADDITIONAL SITE ASSESSMENTS WILL TAKE PLACE AS NEEDED TO TRACK EFFICACY OF RESTORATION TREATMENTS.
ORWA SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES FACT SHEETS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO AID IN CONSERVING AND PROTECTING PLANT BIODIVERSITY, SPECIFICALLY FEDERALLYTHREATENED MIRABILIS MACFARLANEI (MIMA). PREVIOUSLY FUNDED RESEARCH BY THE IDAHO BUREAU OF LANDMANAGEMENT (BLM) HAS ALLOWED US TO DEVELOP A HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL MICROPROPAGATION PROCEDURE FORMIMA. USING MICROPROPAGATION, CLONES OF TWO MIMA GENOTYPES (ONE FROM THE SKOOKUMCHUCKPOPULATION AND ONE FROM LONG GULCH) WILL BE PRODUCED. THE EFFECT OF DIFFERENT RATES OF COMMON RANGEHERBICIDES (MILESTONE, PLATEAU AND TRANSLINE) ON INVASIVE WEEDS (YELLOW STARTHISTLE AND CHEAT GRASS)AND MIMA WILL BE DETERMINED BY MEASURING PLANT MORTALITY, APPEARANCE, AVERAGE PLANT CANOPY DIAMETER,LONGEST SHOOT AND SHOOT DRY WEIGHT.EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE DATA ON SUSCEPTIBILITY OF CONTAINER GROWN MIMA PLANTS TO EACH HERBICIDEWHICH CAN THEN BE USED TO EVALUATE THE FEASIBILITY USING THESE HERBICIDES FOR WEED CONTROL IN NATURALMIMA POPULATIONS. THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THESE HERBICIDE TRIALS CAN BE USED BOTH TO BETTER MANAGENATIVE POPULATIONS OF MIMA AND PROVIDE ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON HOW TO SUCCESSFULLY GROW MIMA(USING CONTAINER PRODUCTION) FOR RESTORATION
CA CESU TRACKING COMMON RAVEN MOVEMENT AND FORAGING BEHAVIOR

CRITICAL HABITAT FOR THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, AS WELL AS SPECIES AT RISK, IS A CORE REASON FOR THE EXISTENCE OF THE WEST EUGENE WETLANDS COMPLEX, OVER 3,500 ACRES OF LEGACY, RESTORED AND PROTECTED WET PRAIRIE, UPLANDS AND OAK SAVANNA AND SHARING THAT ROLE WITH THE COMMUNITY THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH IS ESSENTIAL  ADDITIONALLY, THERE ARE BROAD GOALS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE ROLE OF BLM MANAGED LANDS IN ADDRESSING ISSUES SUCH AS BIODIVERSITY AND CLIMATE CHANGE, INCREASING THE DIVERSITY OF THEIR WORKFORCE, AND EQUITY IN ACCESS TO PUBLIC LANDS  THE PUBLIC S UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF THE SCIENCE BASED MANAGEMENT OF THESE LANDSCAPES REQUIRES THEY BECOME INFORMED AND ENGAGED THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO CONNECT THEM TO THESE LANDS

PINYON JAY  GYMNORHINUS CYANOCEPHALUS  POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED BY 83 5  WITH AN ADDITIONAL 50  DECLINE ANTICIPATED BY 2035  AS A RESULT, PINYON JAYS HAVE RECENTLY BEEN PROPOSED FOR FEDERAL LISTING AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED AND LISTED AS A SPECIES OF CONSERVATION INTEREST BY STATE, FEDERAL, AND NON PROFIT AGENCIES, INCLUDING IMMINENT CONSIDERATION AS A COLORADO BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES  MANAGEMENT TO REDUCE THE EXTENT AND DENSITY OF THEIR PRIMARY HABITAT, PINON JUNIPER WOODLANDS, IS COMMON THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE TO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES, INCREASE DIVERSITY, IMPROVE GRAZING, AND REDUCE FUELS, INCLUDING ON BLM LANDS  HOWEVER, THESE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES MAY HAVE ADVERSE IMPACTS ON PINYON JAY POPULATIONS, PARTICULARLY WHEN SITUATED IN CRITICAL NESTING OR FORAGING HABITAT  IDENTIFYING CURRENT PINYON JAY NESTING COLONIES, HABITAT FEATURES SELECTED BY NESTING COLONIES, HABITAT USE, ABUNDANCE, AND RESPONSE TO MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS CRITICAL PRIORITIES FOR THE PINYON JAY CONSERVATION EFFORT TO ENSURE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ARE CONSISTENT WITH SPECIES RECOVERY AND ENSURE THAT THE SPECIES WILL NOT NEED TO BE FEDERALLY LISTED ON THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION NECESSARY GUIDE ONGOING AND FUTURE BLM MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AND ENSURE THEY DO NOT HAVE UNINTENDED ADVERSE IMPACTS TO PINYON JAYS

THE GUNNISON SAGE GROUSE  GUSG  CENTROCERUS MINIMUS  POPULATION IN SOUTHERN COLORADO IS FRAGMENTED INTO EIGHT DISTINCT POPULATIONS WITH THE MAJORITY  APPROX  85   OF THE CURRENT POPULATION LOCATED IN THE GUNNISON BASIN  2,400 2,800 INDIVIDUALS   REMNANT POPULATIONS ELSEWHERE IN THE REGION REMAIN AT EXTREMELY LOW NUMBERS OR ARE RECENTLY EXTIRPATED DUE TO POOR HABITAT OR IMPACTS FROM HUMAN LAND USES  CURRENTLY, NEST PREDATION IS ASSUMED TO SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE GUSG REPRODUCTIVE POTENTIAL AND IS LIKELY THE PRIMARY FACTOR SUPPRESSING POPULATION RECOVERY  SIGNIFICANT KNOWLEDGE GAPS EXIST IN FOCAL PREDATOR ECOLOGY INCLUDING SPECIES ASSEMBLAGE, OCCUPANCY, AND ABUNDANCE  THIS INFORMATION IS CRITICAL FOR EFFECTIVELY MANAGING PREDATORS FOR GUSG RECOVERY  OUR GOAL FOR THIS PROJECT IS TO ANALYZE THE ROLE OF ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCE IN ARTIFICIALLY SUPPORTING GUSG PREDATOR POPULATIONS  OUR FIRST OBJECTIVE IS TO USE REMOTE TRIGGERED CAMERAS THROUGHOUT THE GUSG RANGE TO ESTIMATE TYPES, DISTRIBUTION, AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF POTENTIAL PREDATORS  THIS WILL INCLUDE A FOCUS ON THOSE AREAS THOUGHT TO SUPPORT PREDATOR POPULATIONS SUCH AS  1  LOCAL WATER TANKS,  2  GREEN FOOD AREAS,  3  GARBAGE DUMPS, AND  4  COMMERCIAL AGRICULTURE  OUR SECOND OBJECTIVE IS TO USE POINT COUNTS TO ESTIMATE DISTRIBUTION AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF POTENTIAL AVIAN PREDATORS AT THE SAME LOCATIONS AS REMOTE CAMERAS  WE WILL SYNTHESIZE THESE DATA INTO A COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF PRIMARY GUSG PREDATORS, LOCATION OF PREDATORS, AND PREDATOR SEASONALITY  BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT AND U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE BIOLOGISTS WILL USE THE INFORMATION TO CREATE SEASONALLY SPECIFIC PREDATOR CONTROL STRATEGIES THAT ARE MORE FOCUSED, EFFICIENT, AND SPATIALLY EXPLICIT THAN CURRENT BROAD PREDATOR CONTROL INITIATIVES

THE   OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO OBTAIN MORE COMPLETE, CURRENT AND ACCURATE   INFORMATION ON THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF RARE INSECT SPECIES OF   CONSERVATION CONCERN IN UTAH  THIS INCLUDES PROVIDING UP TO DATE SPATIAL DATA   FOR THE LOCATIONS OF EVENTUAL THREATENED OR ENDANGERED  TAND E , PROPOSED,   PETITIONED, CONSERVATION AGREEMENT, BLM SENSITIVE AND SPECIES OF GREATEST   CONSERVATION NEED IN UTAH THE   PROJECT WILL INCORPORATE ONGOING INVENTORY AND SURVEY EFFORTS AS WELL AS   TRACK AND ORGANIZE PUBLISHED AND GRAY LITERATURE BY AGENCIES AND PRIVATE   ENTITIES, ARTHROPOD DIGITAL COLLECTIONS RECORDS, AND COMMUNITY SCIENCE   INITIATIVES INTO THE STATE DATABASE  IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT ALL PRODUCTS   RESULTING FROM FUNDING SPENT ON SPECIAL STATUS INSECTS BE MADE AVAILABLE IN   THE MOST USABLE FORMAT PROJECT ACTIVITIES, GOALS AND OBJECTIVES INCLUDE THE   FOLLOWING WORK WILL FOCUS ON INSECT SPECIES PETITIONED FOR FEDERAL   LISTING UNDER THE ESA, BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES, AND DATA LIMITED SPECIES   IDENTIFIED AS RARE AND DECLINING ON UTAH BLM LANDS GATHER INSECT SPECIES DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE DATA   THROUGH FIELD SURVEY WORK, DATABASE SCRAPING, AND RECONCILING HISTORIC   ARTHROPOD COLLECTIONS RECORDS  FURTHER, A TEAM FROM SUU WILL CONDUCT ANNUAL   MONITORING FOR TIGER BEETLES IN THE CORAL PINK SAND DUNES  THIS IS NECESSARY   TO ENSURE THAT RECORDS ARE ACCURATE, THOROUGH, AND NOT DUPLICATIVE, AND THAT   TIGER BEETLE MONITORING CONTINUES THE PROTOCOLS FOR THE LONG TERM POPULATION   DATA SET  SUBMITTING ACCURATE RECORDS INTO THE STATE S   DEVELOPING RARE INSECT DATABASE  TO ENSURE DATA ACCURACY FROM ALL POTENTIAL   SOURCES, TIME CONSUMING DATA QUALITY ASSURANCE AND QUALITY CONTROL OF DATA   WITH APPROPRIATE METADATA IS ESSENTIAL FOR LONG TERM DATA INTEGRITY,   INCLUDING DATA SOURCE ORIGIN  DATA STORED IN THIS DATABASE PERTAINING TO BLM   LANDS WILL BE SHARED WITH THE BLM UTAH STATE OFFICE AS WELL AS FIELD OFFICES   THROUGH ELECTRONIC MEANS AND WILL BE UPDATED ANNUALLY OR AS ADDITIONAL DATA   IS GATHERED  FURTHERMORE, OBSERVATIONS ON OTHER LANDS WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE   BLM PER THE STATE S GRAMA RULES  PROVIDE DETAILS NECESSARY TO UPDATE NATURESERVE   CONSERVATION RANKINGS SUCH AS ESTIMATES OF ABUNDANCE, POPULATION TRENDS, LIFE   HISTORY TRAITS, ASSOCIATED HABITAT TYPES, AND DOCUMENTATION OF CURRENT   THREATS  THE RIC PROGRAM WILL COORDINATE WITH BLM OFFICES AS NECESSARY   INVOLVING FUTURE TASKS SUCH AS VERIFYING OR SURVEYING SENSITIVE OR LISTED   INSECT OCCURRENCES IN PROJECT AREAS

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO ASSESS CURRENT MOJAVE   DESERT TORTOISE  GOPHERUS AGASSIZII  HEREAFTER, DESERT TORTOISE OR TORTOISE    AND BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND HABITAT USE WITHIN THE   BEAVER DAM WASH NATIONAL CONSERVATION AREA  NCA  IN WASHINGTON COUNTY, UTAH    THE RESEARCH INCLUDES A200 ACRE CRITICAL HABITAT STUDY AREA AND THE 21 MILE   PROPOSED HDT OHV ROUTE CORRIDOR IN THE BEAVER DAM WASH NCA  THE PROJECT   INCLUDES SIX SCIENTIFIC OBJECTIVES DETERMINE THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF LIVE TORTOISES AND THEIR        SIGN AND THE RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF TORTOISES IN A 200 ACRE        CRITICAL HABITAT STUDY AREA IN PARTNERSHIP WITH NCA BIOLOGIST, JOHN        KELLAM DETERMINE THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF LIVE TORTOISES, THEIR        SIGN  E G , BURROWS, SCAT , AND INJURED OR DEAD TORTOISES ALONG  AND        WITHIN 200 METERS OF  THE 21 MILE SECTION OF THE PROPOSED HDT IN THE        NCA, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH NCA BIOLOGIST, JOHN KELLAM IDENTIFY THE LOCATION OF KEY HABITAT FEATURES, INCLUDING TORTOISE        BURROWS AND SHELTERS COMPARE CURRENT TORTOISE HABITAT USE, AND HABITAT USE WITH        PREVIOUS STUDIES TO ASSESS CHANGES OVER TIME DETERMINE PRESENCE AND ABUNDANCE, SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION, AND        HABITAT USE OF OTHER BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES DETERMINE THE CURRENT CONDITION OF DESIGNATED CRITICAL TORTOISE        HABITAT, INCLUDING THE LOCATION OF NOXIOUS WEEDS AND NONNATIVE INVASIVE        PLANT SPECIES

THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON THE CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF THE RELICT LEOPARD FROG, WHICH IS A BUREAUSENSITIVE SPECIES  THE RELICT LEOPARD FROG IS MANAGED BY A MULTIAGENCY TEAM  HEREIN, CONSERVATION TEAM  ON WHICH BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  PERSONNEL PARTICIPATE  CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR THIS SPECIESARE STIPULATED UNDER A CONSERVATION AGREEMENT, ASSESSMENT, AND STRATEGY  CAS  TO WHICH SEVERAL BLM OFFICES ARE SIGNATORIES  THIS PROJECT BROADENS AN ESTABLISHED COOPERATIVE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN BLM ANDUNIVERSITY OF NEVADA LAS VEGAS  UNLV  THAT PROVIDES FOR THE PARTICIPATION OF BIOLOGISTS WITH EXTENSIVE EXPERTISE ON THE RELICT LEOPARD FROG THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT DIRECT ON THE GROUND RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR THE RELICT LEOPARD FROG THROUGH SITE SPECIFIC MONITORING, AND HEADSTARTING TRANSLOCATION TO START NEW POPULATIONS AND AUGMENT EXISTING POPULATIONS  AQUATIC SYSTEMS IDENTIFIED BY LAND MANAGERS AS POTENTIAL TRANSLOCATION SITES WILL BE VISITED AND EVALUATED, AND ASSISTANCE PROVIDED TO FACILITATE PERMITTING IF REQUESTED  SITE SPECIFIC MONITORING INFORMATION WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED THROUGH SYSTEMATIC SURVEYS OF EXISTING POPULATIONS  THESE SURVEYS PROVIDE ESTIMATES OF ABUNDANCE AND OTHER DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION USED TO ASSESS THE STATUS OF EACH POPULATION AND IN SUM THE SPECIES AS A WHOLE  THE SURVEYS ARE ALSO USED TO EVALUATE THE SUCCESS OF TRANSLOCATIONS AND AUGMENTATIONS, AS WELL AS TO IDENTIFY AND ASSESS PROACTIVE HABITAT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS SITE SPECIFIC THREATS FROM DISEASE, SPECIFICALLY THE AMPHIBIAN CHYTRID FUNGUS, WILL BE MONITORED AT TARGETED SITES THE PROJECT WILL MAINTAIN A HIGH LEVEL OF INFORMATION DISSEMINATION THROUGH DIRECT SEMI ANNUAL REPORTINGOF ACTIVITIES TO THE MULTIAGENCY CONSERVATION TEAM, AS WELL AS TO PARTICIPATING ENTITIES  RESEARCH INTOSPECIES BIOLOGY OF THE RELICT LEOPARD FROG WILL BE SUPPORTED  PUBLIC PRESENTATIONS AND INTENDED PUBLICATIONOF RESEARCH FINDINGS WILL BE EMPHASIZED TO INCREASE PROFESSIONAL AND PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE OF THE SPECIES UNLV IS ONE OF THE MOST DIVERSE CAMPUSES IN THE NATION, AND THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE EDUCATIONALOPPORTUNITIES FOR A DIVERSITY OF UNLV STUDENTS TO ENGAGE IN MONITORING AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR THE RELICT LEOPARD FROG, AND IN DIRECTED RESEARCH ON THE SPECIES ASPECTS OF THIS PROJECT BUILD UPON EXISTING DATA ON THE RELICT LEOPARD FROG COLLECTED BY UNLV AND PARTNERAGENCIES UNDER PREVIOUS PROJECTS FOLLOWING AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK  PROGRESS IN CONSERVATIONPLANNING WILL BE FACILITATED BY CONDUCTING AN EVALUATION OF EXISTING MONITORING DATA TO ASSESS THE POTENTIAL LONG TERM VIABILITY OF EACH EXTANT RELICT LEOPARD FROG POPULATION, INCLUDING HABITAT CONDITIONS, PREVIOUSMANAGEMENT ACTIONS, AND SUGGESTIONS FOR THE SCOPE AND SCALE OF FUTURE ACTIONS THAT MAY BE NEEDED TOMAINTAIN THE POPULATION  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE CONSERVATION TEAM BY COORDINATINGSEMIANNUAL MEETINGS, EDITING OF TEAM DOCUMENTS AND REPORTS, AND INITIATING A TEN YEAR REVISION OF THECAS

THIS AWARD IS TO COLLECT BASE LINE DATA AND CONTINUE LONG TERM MONITORING OF POPULATIONS OF NECTIVOROUS BATS  LEPTONYCTERIS YERBABUENAE, L  NIVALIS, AND CHOERONYCTERIS MEXICANA  IN NEW MEXICO  DATA COLLECTED INCLUDES IDENTIFICATION OF ROOST SITES, MAIN PLANT RESOURCES, DISTRIBUTION, MOVEMENT PATTERNS, AND MIGRATION CORRIDORS  INFORMATION WILL BE EVALUATED TO DETERMINE THE EFFECTS OF GLOBAL WARMING ON THESE ENDANGERED AND RECENTLY DELISTED SPECIES AND TO INFORM BLM MANAGERS ON FUTURE WIND DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS  THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE IS TO GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE CURRENT STATUS AND BASIC BIOLOGY OF THESE THREE NECTAR BAT SPECIES IN NEW MEXICO  NM  EXECUTIVE ORDER 14008  JANUARY 27, 2021  PLACES THE CLIMATE CRISIS AT THE FOREFRONT OF THIS NATION S FOREIGN POLICY AND NATIONAL SECURITY  BOTH THE PRESERVATION OF BIODIVERSITY AND THE DEPLOYMENT OF CLEAN ENERGY TECHNOLOGIES ARE LISTED AS PRIORITIES  OUR STUDY OF THREE ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES OF NECTAR BATS WILL CONTRIBUTE INFORMATION THAT WILL ASSIST LAND MANAGERS IN MAKING EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS FOR THESE SPECIES, THUS PRESERVING VALUED BIODIVERSITY  MOREOVER, TO INITIATE LARGE SCALE DEVELOPMENT OF WIND ENERGY IN NM, WHILE CONSERVING BIODIVERSITY, IT IS IMPERATIVE TO IDENTIFY HIGH DENSITY FOOD RESOURCE AREAS, ROOST SITES, AND MOVEMENT CORRIDORS THAT SHOULD BE PROTECTED TO ASSURE THE SUCCESSFUL CONSERVATION OF THESE THREE SPECIES OF KEYSTONE POLLINATORS IN NM AS PLANS PROCEED IN NM TO INCREASE WIND DEVELOPMENT, IT IS CRUCIAL THAT POTENTIAL SITES FOR DEVELOPMENT ARE PLACED IN THE BEST AREAS WITHIN THE STATE, BOTH FOR OPTIMAL FUNCTIONING OF WIND DEVELOPMENT AND TO ASSURE NO ADVERSE EFFECTS OCCUR TO WILDLIFE ESPECIALLY BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES, OR ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES  NEGATIVE EFFECTS OF WIND DEVELOPMENT ON BAT SPECIES HAVE PREVIOUSLY BEEN DOCUMENTED  THEREFORE, CAREFUL EVALUATION FOR PLACEMENT OF WIND DEVELOPMENTS IS KEY TO THEIR SUCCESS  THE REVISED 6840 MANUAL  BLM 2008  CALLS FOR BLM TO INITIATE PROACTIVE CONSERVATION MEASURES THAT REDUCE OR ELIMINATE THREATS TO BUREAU SENSITIVE SPECIES TO MINIMIZE THE LIKELIHOOD OF AND NEED FOR LISTING THESE SPECIES UNDER THE ESA  INFORMATION GENERATED FROM THE STUDY CAN BE USED BY BLM, TO MAKE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS REGARDING FORAGING AREAS THAT SHOULD BE PRESERVED, ROOSTING SITES THAT SHOULD BE PROTECTED, AND DISTRIBUTION AND MOVEMENT PATHWAYS WITHIN WHICH WIND DEVELOPMENT SHOULD BE AVOIDED TO ASSURE THE CONTINUED SUCCESSFUL CONSERVATION OF NECTIVOROUS BATS AND THE IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEMS THEY PERPETUATE THROUGH POLLINATION AND SEED DISPERSAL RESEARCH BENEFITS THE PUBLIC DIRECTLY AND INDIRECTLY  DIRECTLY, WE WORK CLOSELY WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN THIS AREA AND EDUCATE THEM REGARDING THE BIOLOGICAL ROLE OF NECTIVOROUS BATS AND THE IMPORTANCE OF THEIR CONSERVATION  WE PROVIDED A WORKSHOP TO THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AT ANIMAS HIGH SCHOOL ABOUT OUR RESEARCH IN 2019 AND PLAN ON DOING SO AGAIN  THESE INTERACTIONS DIRECTLY INCREASE PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE OF FEDERALLY LISTED, BUREAU SENSITIVE, AND RARE WILDLIFE ON BLM MANAGED LANDS, IN A RURAL, LOW INCOME, AND DIVERSE COMMUNITY  RESULTS OF OUR FINDINGS WILL BE PUBLISHED IN PEER REVIEWED ACADEMIC JOURNALS, AS WELL AS SHARED WITH THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, NEW MEXICO GAME AND FISH, THE BLM AND MALPAI BORDERLANDS GROUP  A NON PROFIT COMMUNITY ORGANIZATION ENGAGED IN LOCAL CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES IN THE REGION   SCIENTIFIC RESULTS WILL BE PRESENTED AT CONFERENCES, INCLUDING THE NORTH AMERICAN SOCIETY FOR BAT RESEARCH, AMERICAN SOCIETY OF MAMMOLOGISTS, THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY, AND AT DEPARTMENT SEMINARS AT NM STATE UNIVERSITY AND COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY  INDIRECTLY, THE PUBLIC BENEFITS BY RESEARCH FOCUSED ON PROTECTING BIODIVERSITY
CA CESU REPRODUCTION OF BLUNT NOSED LEOPARD LIZARDS IN WILD AND  CAPTIVELY MANAGED POPULATIONS

THE   OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO ASSESS CURRENT MOJAVE DESERT TORTOISE  GOPHERUS   AGASSIZII  HEREAFTER, DESERT TORTOISE OR TORTOISE  POPULATION STATUS, AND   LONG TERM POPULATION DEMOGRAPHIC AND POPULATION TRENDS WITHIN THE RED CLIFFS   NATIONAL CONSERVATION AREA  NCA , AND THE DESERT TORTOISE STATUS WITHIN THE   BEAVER DAM WASH NCA THERE   ARE TWO PHASES PROPOSED WITH THIS PROJECT PHASE   1 THE   PRIMARY GOAL IS TO DETERMINE CURRENT POPULATION STATUS, AND LONG TERM   POPULATION DEMOGRAPHIC AND POPULATION TRENDS WITHIN THE RED CLIFFS NCA, THE   PRIMARY CONSERVATION AREA IN THE UPPER VIRGIN RIVER RECOVERY UNIT  UVRRU     OBTAINING POPULATION ESTIMATES IN CALENDAR YEAR 2023, EXACTLY 25 YEARS SINCE   FULL SCALE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MONITORING PROGRAM, WILL ALLOW FOR TREND   EVALUATION OF ONE TORTOISE GENERATION, WHICH IS IDENTIFIED AS AN IMPORTANT   RECOVERY CRITERION, AND WILL PROVIDE FOR AN UNDERSTANDING OF LONG TERM   IMPACTS FROM RECENT LARGE SCALE FIRES IN THE RED CLIFFS NCA DURING THE SUMMER   OF 2020 SPECIFIC   OBJECTIVES FOR PHASE 1 INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING  1    COMPLETE EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING BY SAMPLING LONG TERM DESERT TORTOISE   MONITORING PLOTS IN MANAGEMENT ZONES 2, 3, 4, AND 5  2    HIRE, SUPERVISE, TRAIN, AND COORDINATE FIELD CREW  3    TRACK RADIOTELEMETERED TORTOISES TO QUANTIFY ABOVE GROUND ACTIVITY DURING   SURVEYS  4    EVALUATE AND ASSESS SIZE CLASS DISTRIBUTION, SEX RATIOS, GROWTH RATES ON   MARKED ANIMALS, AND HEALTH  5    COLLECT PRESENCE DATA ON BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES OBSERVED ON TRANSECTS AND IN   THE FIELD  6    ANALYZE MONITORING DATA  1998 TO 2023  AND ASSESS ADULT POPULATION DENSITY,   ABUNDANCE AND LONG TERM TRENDS  7    EVALUATE POPULATION STATUS AND ASSESS EFFECTIVENESS OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS    E G , FENCING, HABITAT REHABILITATION, TRANSLOCATION, ETC    8    PROVIDE AN ASSESSMENT OF PLANT COMMUNITY STATUS ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE  E G ,   SPECIES PRESENT,   COVER   AND 9    ANALYZE DATA AND PREPARE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS FOR BLM AND AGENCY   PARTNERS PHASE   2 UPDATE AND REFINE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF TORTOISE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE   IN THE NCA BY SYNTHESIZING HISTORICAL DISTRIBUTION, DEMOGRAPHIC DATA AND   RESEARCH CONDUCTED WITHIN THE NCA AND ASSESS RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF CURRENT   TORTOISE POPULATIONS SPECIFIC   OBJECTIVES FOR PHASE 2 INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING  1    COMPILE HISTORICAL REPORTS AND RESEARCH PAPERS ON TORTOISE POPULATIONS IN THE   NCA  2    DIGITIZE HISTORICAL DATA INTO GEODATABASE, WHEN POSSIBLE  3    SUMMARIZE DEMOGRAPHICS, POPULATION STATUS AND HISTORICAL DISTRIBUTION OF   TORTOISE POPULATIONS IN THE NCA  4    COMPARE HISTORICAL DISTRIBUTION TO CURRENT BY CONDUCTING WEEKLY SIGHT VISITS   DURING THE SPRING FOCUSING ON OCCUPIED HABITAT AND ACTIVE BURROWS  5    IDENTIFY MARKED TORTOISES AND ASSESS GROWTH AND HEALTH, WHEN POSSIBLE  AND 6    ASSESS RELATIVE ABUNDANCES OF TORTOISES IN THE BEAVER DAM WASH NCA

A PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FACILITATE DATA SHARING AND DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES BETWEEN BLM NM AND NHNM, WHICH ARE CRUCIAL TO CONDUCTING AND IMPROVING DAILY BLM ACTIVITIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES AND OTHER BIOLOGICAL RESOURCES  SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL WORK ON ENTERING BACKLOGGED BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES DATA, UPDATE CONSERVATION RANKS WITH THIS DATA, AND UPDATE THE ELEMENT OCCURRENCES FOR THESE SPECIES  WE WILL ALSO BUILD A COMPREHENSIVE PORTFOLIO OF NEW MEXICO CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION AREAS IN A GEODATABASE TO BE MADE AVAILABLE ON THE WEB WITH SUPPORTING MATERIALS AND REPORTS THAT CAN DIRECTLY SUPPORT BLM STAFF EFFORTS TO SUSTAIN AND ENHANCE SENSITIVE SPECIES POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT THE STATE  LASTLY, WE WILL EXPAND BLM S CAPACITY TO SURVEY AND MONITOR SENSITIVE SPECIES TO ENSURE THEIR LONG TERM SUSTAINABILITY UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF CLIMATE CHANGE ACCORDINGLY, THIS PROJECT HAS SPECIFIC APPLICATIONS FOR ADDRESSING THE STATUS AND TRENDS OF BLM SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES IN THE CONTEXT CLIMATE CHANGE THAT ARE IN KEEPING WITH EXECUTIVE ORDER 14008  TACKLING THE CLIMATE CRISIS AT HOME AND ABROAD THIS SUPPORT IS BEING REQUESTED TO MEET NHNM S AND BLM S MUTUAL GOALS TO CONDUCT BIOLOGICAL STUDIES AND COLLECT, STORE, AND PROVIDE ACCESS TO STATEWIDE COMPREHENSIVE BIOLOGICAL AND NATURAL HERITAGE DATA IN NEW MEXICO TO INFORM BLM STAFF AND THE PUBLIC  EXPECTED PRODUCTS ARE THE ADDING OF CURRENT AND HISTORICAL BLM OBSERVATIONS ON BLM SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES INTO A DATABASE FOR BLM STAFF ACCESS  A SUITE OF POTENTIAL CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION SITES FOR SENSITIVE SPECIES ON BLM LANDS HELD IN A WEB BASED APPLICATION, AND SPECIES SPECIFIC POPULATION DATA TO EVALUATE THE STATUS AND TRENDS OF SENSITIVE SPECIES TO SUPPORT THEIR MANAGEMENT ON BLM LANDS  THESE PRODUCTS WILL HAVE DIRECT APPLICATIONS FOR MEETING ALL SEVEN OF THE BLM NEW MEXICO THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES PROGRAM STRATEGIC GOALS AND THE EIGHT OPPORTUNITIES AS LISTED IN THE NOFO  THAT IS, HAVING UP TO DATE INFORMATION ON BLM SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES, A PORTFOLIO OF POTENTIAL CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION AREAS, AND DEVELOPING A STRATEGIC AND COHERENT SURVEY AND MONITORING PROGRAM DIRECTLY SUPPORTS ON THE GROUND ACTIONS FOR CONSERVING AND RECOVERING THESE SPECIES  DETERMINING THE SPECIES STATUS AND CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITIES  ADDS TO THE KNOWLEDGE BASE FOR THESE SPECIES  SUPPORTS PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES  AND CAN LEAD TO AUGMENTING LISTED SPECIES AND SUPPORTING ESA CONSULTATIONS AND CONSERVATION PROGRAMS FINALLY, THE PUBLIC FACE OF THE NMCIS THROUGH ITS EASILY ACCESSIBLE WEBPAGE AND CITIZEN SCIENCE INITIATIVES DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF SENSITIVE SPECIES AND BLM S ROLE IN THEIR CONSERVATION  THIS IS CENTRAL TO NATURAL HERITAGE NEW MEXICO S MISSION OF PROVIDING CURRENT SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION, RESEARCH, AND EDUCATION ON CONSERVATION OF NEW MEXICO S BIOTA AND NATURAL RESOURCES TO SCIENTISTS, STUDENTS, GOVERNMENT AND BUSINESS LEADERS, LAND MANAGERS, AND THE PUBLIC

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT PLANT   COMMUNITY AND LUPINE SAMPLING IN TREATED AREAS AT FIR BUTTE TO DETERMINE THE   EFFECTIVENESS OF THE HABITAT RESTORATION TREATMENTS FOR IMPROVING HABITAT   QUALITY AND INCREASING COVER OF KINCAID S LUPINE AT THE SITE  THE SOUTHEAST   PORTION OF THE SITE WAS TREATED WITH HERBICIDE IN 2020 AND 2021  IN 2021, THE   AREA WAS SEEDED WITH A DIVERSE MIX OF NECTAR SPECIES INCLUDING KINCAID S   LUPINE  WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE HABITAT MONITORING IN THE TREATED AREA  WE   ALSO PROPOSE CONTINUED LUPINE MONITORING ACROSS THE SITE TO1  ASSESS THE   STATUS OF THE POPULATION AND2  DETERMINE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES   ON LUPINE IN THE SE CORNER

THIS PROJECT IS RELATED TO RECOVERY OF THE RARE PLANT MACFARLANE S FOUR O CLOCK  MIRABILIS MACFARLENEI   MIMA2  AND THE CANYON GRASSLAND HABITATS WHERE IT IS FOUND  INTACT CANYON GRASSLANDS OF THE SALMON AND SNAKE RIVER WATERSHEDS PROTECT RIVERINE SYSTEMS FROM SEDIMENTATION AND PROVIDE RESOURCES FOR NATIVE WILDLIFE SUCH AS MULE DEER AND BIGHORN SHEEP AND A MYRIAD OF BIRDS AND OTHER FAUNA  MIMA2 PRESENCE IN THE CANYONS ECOSYSTEM ALSO RELIES ON HIGH QUALITY HABITAT THAT PERFORMS THESE ESSENTIAL ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS  IN THIS PROJECT WE WILL ASSESS HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR MIMA2 OUT PLANTING SITES  THIS WILL NOT ONLY FURTHER OUR KNOWLEDGE ABOUT SITE SUITABILITY BUT ALSO EVALUATE THE HABITAT RESILIENCY AND RESTORATION POTENTIAL OF HABITATS
THE GENETIC STATUS, POPULATION STRUCTURE, AND CONNECTIVITY IN THE FEDERALLY-LISTED ENDANGERED SPECIES CAULANTHUS CALIFORNICUS (S. WATSON) PAYSON

THICKLEAF BLADDERPOD (PHYSARIA PACHYPHYLLA) IS A BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES IN MONTANA, FOUND IN THE PRYOR DESERT THAT STRADDLES THE STATE LINE, AND WHERE IT HAS ALSO BEEN COLLECTED TWICE IN CONTIGUOUS AREAS OF WYOMING. SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED FOR THIS PROJECT TO ADDRESS ITS DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT IN BOTH STATES, ITS POPULATION AND HABITAT CONDITIONS, AND COMPILE RESULTS IN A RANGEWIDE STATUS REPORT. PHYSARIA PACHYPHYLLA IS UNDER REVIEW FOR LISTING AS THREATENED. THIS STUDY WILL INFORM ALL BLM OFFICES AND MAY INFORM THE REVIEW DECISION. PHYSARIA PACHYPHYLLA LIES WITHIN THE PRYOR FOOTHILLS AREA OF CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERN (ACEC; BLM 2021) AND WITHIN A MINING PROPOSAL AREA. IT IS ALSO IN AN AREA OF WILD HORSE MANAGEMENT, OFFROAD VEHICLE ACTIVITY, AND WEED MANAGEMENT.THIS SPECIES IS IN A GENUS OF INTEREST TO BOTANISTS AND OF POTENTIAL INTEREST TO PHARMACEUTICAL COMPANIES. OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT PROVIDE A REFERENCE OF INTEREST TO BOTANISTS, CONSERVATIONISTS, RESEARCHERS AND THE PUBLIC INTERESTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE PRYOR FOOTHILLS.PHYSARIA PACHYPHYLLA IS RANKED GLOBALLY IMPERILED OR VULNERABLE (G2G3), WITH THE CORRESPONDING STATE RANK IN MONTANA (S2S3), AND STATE CRITICALLY IMPERILED IN WYOMING (S1). IT WAS DESCRIBED BY GRADY AND O'KANE (2007), PUBLISHED IN FLORA OF NORTH AMERICA (O'KANE 2010), AND PETITIONED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 2021. IT IS CURRENTLY UNDER REVIEW BY U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (2022). THIS PROJECT WILL INFORM BLM STATUS IN BOTH STATES, AND MAY INFORM THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE REVIEW.

DESERT YELLOWHEAD IS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (USDI FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE 2002). THERE ARE ONLY TWO KNOWN POPULATIONS OF DESERT YELLOWHEAD IN THE  WORLD, BOTH POPULATIONS OCCUR ON LANDS MANAGED BY THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM)  LANDER FIELD OFFICE. IN 2021 WE INITIATED A STUDY THAT MEASURED BOTH SEXUAL AND ASEXUAL  REPRODUCTIVE BIOLOGY, WHILE MEASURING WEATHER CONDITIONS TO ESTIMATE THE DEGREE TO WHICH  MOISTURE LIMITED THIS THREATENED PLANT. THE CURRENT PROJECT ENDS IN 2022, BUT CONTINUAL DROUGHT  CONDITIONS WILL LIKELY LIMIT OUR INFERENCE ABOUT REPRODUCTION IN THIS PLANT. WE ARE PROPOSING TO  CONTINUE TO MONITOR CLIMATE AND MEASURE REPRODUCTION, AS WELL AS DEVELOP A PRACTICAL MONITORING  SCHEME FOR BOTH POPULATIONS. IN 2018, WE COLLECTED DESERT YELLOWHEAD SEEDS AS PART OF A POLLINATION AND SEED SET STUDY,  BECAUSE SPECIALIZED PLANTS CAN HAVE SPECIALIZED POLLINATORS. IF THESE SPECIALIZED POLLINATORS  DECLINE, SEED PRODUCTION CAN BE GREATLY REDUCED. HOWEVER, WE DISCOVERED THAT POLLINATORS DID  NOT LIMIT SEED PRODUCTION IN DESERT YELLOWHEAD DURING 2018, BUT SOMETHING ELSE DID. SIXTEEN  PERCENT OF SEEDS WERE VIABLE IN THE INSECT POLLINATED TREATMENT OF THE SAND DRAW POPULATION AND  0% OF SEEDS WERE VIABLE IN THE CEDAR RIM POPULATION. WE ARE PROPOSING TO CONTINUE TO MONITOR  CLIMATE AND MEASURE REPRODUCTION. CONTINUING TO STUDY THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE ON THE REPRODUCTION  OF DESERT YELLOWHEAD WOULD PROVIDE A MUCH BETTER DEPICTION OF THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE  POPULATIONS TO FURTHER PROTECT THIS RARE SPECIES. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MONITORING  BASED ON PAST RESEARCH IN BOTH DESERT YELLOWHEAD POPULATIONS TO ESTIMATE CHANGES IN POPULATIONS  OVER TIME. OUR PROPOSAL DEVELOPED FROM THE CURRENT INTERESTS IN MONITORING RARE SPECIES, THE  POTENTIAL DECREASE IN ANNUAL PRECIPITATION, INCREASES IN AIR TEMPERATURE AND EVAPOTRANSPIRATION,  AND THE LACK OF KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE ECOLOGY AND REPRODUCTION OF DESERT YELLOWHEAD. DESERT YELLOWHEAD IS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (USDI FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE 2002). THIS UNIQUE PLANT WAS DISCOVERED BY ROBERT DORN IN 1990 AT SAND DRAW  (DORN 1991) AND A SECOND POPULATION, CEDAR RIM, WAS FOUND ~8 KM DOWNWIND IN 2010 (HEIDEL  ET AL. 2011). THESE ARE THE ONLY TWO KNOWN POPULATIONS OF DESERT YELLOWHEAD IN THE WORLD.  CONTINUING TO STUDY THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE ON THE REPRODUCTION OF DESERT YELLOWHEAD WOULD  PROVIDE A MUCH BETTER DEPICTION OF THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE POPULATIONS TO FURTHER PROTECT THIS  THREATENED PLANT. A PRACTICAL AND INFORMATIVE MONITORING SCHEME WILL ALSO APPRISE THE BLM OF  WHAT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS MAY BE BENEFICIAL TO CONSERVE THIS RARE SPECIES. CONTINUING TO STUDY THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE ON THE REPRODUCTION OF DESERT YELLOWHEAD WOULD  PROVIDE A MUCH BETTER DEPICTION OF THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE POPULATIONS TO FURTHER PROTECT THIS RARE  SPECIES. RESULTS MAY BE USED TO ADDRESS QUESTIONS RAISED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR THIS THREATENED  SPECIES. DATA WILL BE STORED AND AVAILABLE FOR USE FROM WYNDD'S WEBSITE  (HTTPS://WYNDD.ORG/DATA_EXPLORER.PHP

1. STATEMENTS OF NEED: SMALL ROCKCRESS (BOECHERA PUSILLA) IS KNOWN FROM ONE POPULATION IN THE WORLD,  IN THE BLM ROCK SPRINGS FIELD OFFICE. ITS GLOBAL HERITAGE RANK POSTED BY NATURESERVE IS GLOBALLY  CRITICALLY IMPERILED (G1) SO ITS STATE RANK IN WYOMING IS STATE CRITICALLY IMPERILED (S1). BOECHERA PUSILLA HAS BEEN COMPLETELY SURVEYED. MONITORING STARTED IN 1988, AND REPLICATED TEN TIMES BETWEEN 2003-2017.  DOCUMENTING NUMBERS THAT RANGED FROM 3-23% OF 1988 NUMBERS. IT WAS PETITIONED FOR LISTING IN 2007 AND  BY 2018 WAS DETERMINED AS NOT WARRANTED (USFWS 2018). 2. PURPOSE: TWO YEARS OF MONITORING DATA WILL BE COLLECTED AFTER A SIX YEAR HIATUS TO DOCUMENT  PERSISTENCE, AUGMENTED WITH FECUNDITY DATA, AND PROVIDING COORDINATION WITH THE FIELD OFFICE REGARDING SITE CONDITIONS.  3. OBJECTIVES: THIS STUDY IS DESIGNED TO CORROBORATE THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE INTERPRETATION  (2018) THAT SPECIES' VIABILITY IS NOT AT RISK.  4. METHODS/APPROACH: THE KNOWN WYOMING LOCATION WILL BE REVISITED TO CONFIRM INTACT CONDITIONS, SEEK  ANY EVIDENCE OF TRENDS OR CHANGES TO SPECIES' EXTENT AND LOCAL DISTRIBUTIONS, SPECIES' NUMBERS, HABITAT  REQUIREMENTS, LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION, AND POTENTIAL THREATS. THEN, SURVEY TARGETS BETWEEN IDAHO AND  WYOMING POPULATIONS WILL BE IDENTIFIED BASED ON THE SURFACE GEOLOGY AND PHOTOINTERPRETATION. ANY NEW  LOCATIONS WILL BE DOCUMENTED WITH VOUCHER SPECIMENS AND BY PHOTOGRAPHING THE SPECIES ACROSS THE  ENCOUNTERED RANGE OF PHENOLOGICAL STAGES, LIFE HISTORY AND HABITAT CONDITIONS. RESULTS OF THE 2023  FIELDWORK WILL BE PRESENTED INTO A DETAILED STATUS REPORT UPDATING SPECIES' STATUS IN WYOMING. 5. TIMETABLE OR MILESTONES: PLANS WILL BE COMMUNICATED BEFORE THE START OF FIELDWORK (SPRING 2023), AND  OUTCOME WILL BE COMMUNICATED AFTER THE FIELD SEASONS. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE PREPARED OF SURVEY RESULTS.  THE FINAL REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED BY OR BEFORE SPRING 2025
THE STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF REGAL FRITILLARY AND MONARCH BUTTERFLIES IN WYOMING

BOISE STATE UNIVERSITY, INTERMOUNTAIN BIRD OBSERVATORY PROPOSES TO MONITOR AND INVENTORY THREATENED YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO (YBCU) POPULATIONS ON POTENTIAL HABITAT ON BLM MANAGED LAND IN THREE IDAHO FIELD OFFICES (SHOSHONE, POCATELLO, UPPER SNAKE). THIS WORK IS PART OF A MULTI-AGENCY (IDFG, BOR, USFWS, OSC) EFFORT TO EXAMINE YBCU OCCUPANCY ACROSS POTENTIAL HABITAT ON BLM LANDS AND OTHER PUBLIC LANDS IN IDAHO. IBO WILL USE THREE APPROACHES TO INVENTORY YBCU HABITAT ON SUITABLE BLM LANDS: 1) FWS-SANCTIONED PLAYBACK CALL SURVEYS, 2) REMOTE RECORDING DEVICES, AND 3) NEST SEARCHES. AREAS WILL BE PRIORITIZED BY HABITAT MODEL PREDICTIONS AND BY BLM FIELD OFFICE MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES.

THIS PROJECT   AIMS TO LOOK AT HOW THIS SPECIES RESPONDS TO VARIOUS MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES   AND DETERMINE WHICH MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES MAY GIVE THE WILLAMETTE DAISY SPECIES THE BEST   CHANCE AT SURVIVAL. THIS PROJECT WILL   CONTRIBUTE TO THE ANALYSIS OF THE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT TREATMENTS ON THE   ESTABLISHMENT OF THE WILLAMETTE DAISY AND THE SURROUNDING PLANT COMMUNITY.

THIS PROJECT WILL MONITOR POPULATIONS AND RESTORE HABITAT FOR BUREAU SENSITIVE, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED SPECIES (HEREIN REFERRED TO AS T&E/S SPECIES) IN MULTIPLE COASTAL WATERSHEDS ON THE SOUTHERN OREGON COAST; WITH A FOCUS ON LANDS WITHIN AND ADJACENT TO THE BLM'S AREAS OF CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERN (ACEC'S) IN THE NEW RIVER AND HUNTER CREEK WATERSHEDS, AND IN THE ELK RIVER-BRUSH CREEK-EUCHRE CREEK WATERSHED DIVIDE.

THIS PROJECT WOULD DIRECTLY ALIGN WITH DOI PRIORITY NUMBER FOUR, WORKING TO CONSERVE AT LEAST 30% EACH OF OUR LANDS AND WATERS BY THE YEAR 2030. THE COMPILATION OF SLICKSPOT PEPPERGRASS MONITORING DATA DIRECTLY INFORMS CURRENT AND FUTURE RESTORATION ACTIONS CRITICAL FOR T&E SPECIES RECOVERY AND FUTURE DELISTING. TOGETHER THESE ACTIVITIES WILL PROVIDE THE MOST UP-TO-DATE ASSESSMENT OF THE POPULATION STATUS, THREATS AND DISTURBANCES OF SLICKSPOT PEPPERGRASS, A FEDERALLY IDENTIFIED THREATENED SPECIES, IN THE MICROSITESWHERE IT IS FOUND, AND AN ESTIMATE OF THE HEALTH OF THE SURROUNDING HABITAT. THIS WILL GIVE THE BLM THE INFORMATION IT REQUIRES TO ADDRESS AND RESPOND TO RECOVERY AND RESTORATION EFFORTS FOR THIS SPECIES, AND DETERMINE THE EXTENT TO WHICH THREATS IDENTIFIED IN THE SSA AREMITIGATED. ADDITIONALLY, THIS INFORMATION WILL PROTECT BIODIVERSITY AND WORK TO SLOW EXTINCTION RATES ON ALL UNITED STATES' LANDS, ASTATED PRIORITY OF THE DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR.

THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND THE BODY OF KNOWLEDGE FOR 4 BUREAU SENSITIVE PLANT SPECIES IN THE COOS BAY BLM DISTRICT, OREGON. BY DOING SO, THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT EFFORTS TO INCREASE THE CLIMATE RESILIENCY OFTHESE SPECIES AND TO MAINTAIN THEIR CONTRIBUTION TO GLOBAL BIODIVERSITY.
